objective: To introduce the idea of robots and what they can do.
explanation:
• Robots are machines that can do tasks. 
 • Some look like humans, others like cars or animals. 
 • They help people by doing work.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Robot Toy Sorting
Materials Needed: Toy robots, toy animals, and cars.
Steps to Follow:
• Mix the toys together.
• Ask child to find only the robots.
• Talk about what makes them different.
What Should Be Achieved:
Identify robots among other toys.
What is Gained:
• Categorization
• Observation
steps: Ask child to find only the robots.
Talk about what makes them different.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Move Like a Robot Game
Materials Needed: None.
Steps to Follow:
• You act like a robot with stiff arms.
• Ask child to copy your moves.
• Give simple commands: turn, pick, walk.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand how robots move and follow commands.
What is Gained:
• Physical activity
• Listening skill
steps: You act like a robot with stiff arms.
Ask child to copy your moves.
Give simple commands: turn, pick, walk.
activities.achieved: Understand how robots move and follow commands.

objective: To understand how AI helps at home.
explanation:
• Some machines can be smart helpers like Alexa or Siri. 
 • They listen and answer questions. 
 • They make life easier.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Guess the Helper Sound
Materials Needed: Sound clips from AI devices, speaker.
Steps to Follow:
• Play sounds (like Alexa alarm or Siri voice).
• Ask child to guess what it is.
• Talk about how we use it.
What Should Be Achieved:
Connect sounds to AI helpers.
What is Gained:
• Listening
• Real-world connection
steps: Play sounds (like Alexa alarm or Siri voice).
Ask child to guess what it is.
Talk about how we use it.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Helper Matching Game
Materials Needed: Picture cards (AI speaker, vacuum, lights).
Steps to Follow:
• Show real-life situation (like cleaning).
• Ask child to match it with the right AI helper.
What Should Be Achieved:
Match tasks with smart helpers.
What is Gained:
• Memory building
• Logical thinking
steps: Ask child to match it with the right AI helper.

objective: To explore how machines understand voice.
explanation:
• Some machines understand when we speak. 
 • They can follow simple voice commands. 
 • This is called voice recognition.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Command the Toy
Materials Needed: Talking toy (or pretend one), flashcards.
Steps to Follow:
• Show card with action like “Jump” or “Turn.”
• Say the word to the toy.
• Pretend it listens and does it.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand how voice can control actions.
What is Gained:
• Imagination
• Concept of input/output
steps: Show card with action like “Jump” or “Turn.”
Say the word to the toy.
Pretend it listens and does it.
activities.achieved: Understand how voice can control actions.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Simon Says with a Twist
Materials Needed: None.
Steps to Follow:
• Play Simon Says, but say you’re a robot.
• Give voice commands like “Simon says wave.”
• Sometimes don’t say “Simon says.”
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice voice-based instructions.
What is Gained:
• Focus
• Fun introduction to voice control
steps: Play Simon Says, but say you’re a robot.
Give voice commands like “Simon says wave.”

objective: To introduce how some machines can see using cameras.
explanation:
• Some machines have cameras like eyes. 
 • They can look at things and understand them. 
 • This is called computer vision.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Find the Object
Materials Needed: Picture cards, toy camera.
Steps to Follow:
• Show picture card of an object (like a ball).
• Ask child to “scan” the room with toy camera to find it.
• Talk about how machines do the same.
What Should Be Achieved:
Link visuals with AI seeing.
What is Gained:
• Search skills
• Awareness of computer vision
steps: Show picture card of an object (like a ball).
Ask child to “scan” the room with toy camera to find it.
Talk about how machines do the same.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Camera or Not?
Materials Needed: Mix of toy items, some with pretend cameras.
Steps to Follow:
• Show toys and ask if it has a “camera.”
• Talk about what a machine needs to see.
What Should Be Achieved:
Identify vision tools.
What is Gained:
• Observation
• Categorization
steps: Show toys and ask if it has a “camera.”
Talk about what a machine needs to see.

objective: To help children see how machines learn from patterns.
explanation:
• AI learns by looking at patterns. 
 • It can find what comes next. 
 • Just like we do in games and puzzles.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Shape Pattern Game
Materials Needed: Blocks or shapes in colors.
Steps to Follow:
• Make a simple pattern (red, blue, red, blue).
• Ask child what comes next.
• Let them make their own.
What Should Be Achieved:
Identify and create patterns.
What is Gained:
• Sequencing
• Logic development
steps: Make a simple pattern (red, blue, red, blue).

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Finish the Row
Materials Needed: Printed sheets with missing patterns.
Steps to Follow:
• Show pattern with missing piece.
• Ask child to fill it.
What Should Be Achieved:
Predict based on patterns.
What is Gained:
• Critical thinking
• Visual learning

objective: To understand how machines sort things into groups.
explanation:
• AI can group things by color, size, or shape. 
 • It helps organize and find things quickly. 
 • This is called classification.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Toy Sorting Time
Materials Needed: Mixed toys (shapes, sizes, colors).
Steps to Follow:
• Ask child to sort toys by color, then shape.
• Talk about how machines do the same.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice sorting by features.
What is Gained:
• Decision-making
• Intro to data sorting
steps: Ask child to sort toys by color, then shape.
Talk about how machines do the same.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Food or Not?
Materials Needed: Toy food items and non-food toys.
Steps to Follow:
• Mix toys and ask child to find only food.
• Let them explain why.
What Should Be Achieved:
Separate based on category.
What is Gained:
• Classification
• Verbal reasoning
materials: Toy food items and non-food toys.
steps: Mix toys and ask child to find only food.

objective: To explore how machines can listen and understand sound.
explanation:
• Some AI tools can hear sounds. 
 • They recognize words and noises. 
 • This is how voice assistants work.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Clap Pattern Game
Materials Needed: None.
Steps to Follow:
• Clap a pattern (e.g., clap clap pause).
• Ask child to repeat it.
• Explain how machines also listen to sound patterns.
What Should Be Achieved:
Follow and repeat audio patterns.
What is Gained:
• Sound recognition
• Memory building
steps: Clap a pattern (e.g., clap clap pause).
Explain how machines also listen to sound patterns.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Sound Sorting
Materials Needed: Audio clips (animal, machine, voice).
Steps to Follow:
• Play each sound.
• Ask child to name the sound type.
What Should Be Achieved:
Identify sound types.
What is Gained:
• Auditory learning
• Categorization
steps: Ask child to name the sound type.

objective: To introduce how some toys use AI to respond.
explanation:
• Some toys can talk, sing, or move. 
 • They have sensors and AI inside. 
 • They can react to what we do.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Meet My Smart Toy
Materials Needed: Smart toy (or pretend one).
Steps to Follow:
• Show toy’s features (talking, blinking).
• Ask child to explore and describe it.
What Should Be Achieved:
Notice interactive features.
What is Gained:
• Observation
• Tech awareness
steps: Ask child to explore and describe it.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Pretend to Be Smart Toy
Materials Needed: None.
Steps to Follow:
• Child pretends to be a smart toy.
• You give commands, they respond like the toy.
What Should Be Achieved:
Roleplay of AI response.
What is Gained:
• Imaginative play
• Understanding AI reaction
steps: Child pretends to be a smart toy.
You give commands, they respond like the toy.

objective: To explore how robots can act like friends or helpers.
explanation:
• Some robots can talk, dance, or play. 
 • They can feel like friendly companions. 
 • People use them for fun or help.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Robot Dance Time
Materials Needed: Music player, robot toy (optional).
Steps to Follow:
• Play music and do robot dance moves.
• Let child copy and create moves.
What Should Be Achieved:
Enjoy moving like robots.
What is Gained:
• Creativity
• Motor skills
steps: Play music and do robot dance moves.
Let child copy and create moves.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Talk to the Robot
Materials Needed: Robot toy or picture.
Steps to Follow:
• Have a pretend chat with the robot.
• Ask child to tell it something.
What Should Be Achieved:
Pretend interaction.
What is Gained:
• Communication skills
• Imagination
steps: Have a pretend chat with the robot.
Ask child to tell it something.

objective: To understand how AI helps people learn new things.
explanation:
• AI can help us read, count, and play learning games. 
 • It gives feedback and teaches. 
 • Like a helper teacher.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
AI Learning App Time
Materials Needed: Educational app or demo video.
Steps to Follow:
• Let child try or watch learning app.
• Ask what it teaches.
What Should Be Achieved:
Observe AI-based learning.
What is Gained:
• Tech exposure
• Early digital literacy
steps: Let child try or watch learning app.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Teach the Robot
Materials Needed: Toy or puppet.
Steps to Follow:
• Ask child to teach ABC or 123 to robot.
• Pretend robot repeats it.
What Should Be Achieved:
Role reversal of AI and user.
What is Gained:
• Confidence
• Understanding AI as learner
steps: Ask child to teach ABC or 123 to robot.
activities.achieved: Role reversal of AI and user.

objective: To explore how AI can talk or reply to people.
explanation:
• Some machines can reply when we talk. 
 • They use AI to understand and answer. 
 • Like voice assistants and chatbots.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Hello Machine
Materials Needed: Phone or toy with voice assistant.
Steps to Follow:
• Say “Hello” and wait for reply.
• Try other simple phrases.
What Should Be Achieved:
Experience talking to AI.
What is Gained:
• Communication
• Curiosity
materials: Phone or toy with voice assistant.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Echo Game
Materials Needed: None.
Steps to Follow:
• You say something, child repeats like a robot.
• Swap roles.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand how AI listens and talks.
What is Gained:
• Fun learning
• Speech awareness
steps: You say something, child repeats like a robot.
activities.achieved: Understand how AI listens and talks.

objective: To recognize AI characters in shows.
explanation:
• Some cartoons have robots or smart characters. 
 • They show how AI helps or thinks. 
 • Kids can connect real AI with stories.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Find the AI Friend
Materials Needed: Watch a cartoon episode.
Steps to Follow:
• Watch and pause when robot or AI comes.
• Talk about what it does.
What Should Be Achieved:
Notice AI roles in media.
What is Gained:
• Observation
• Media literacy
steps: Watch and pause when robot or AI comes.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Draw the AI Character
Materials Needed: Paper, crayons.
Steps to Follow:
• Ask child to draw their favorite smart cartoon character.
• Talk about what makes it smart.
What Should Be Achieved:
Expression through art.
What is Gained:
• Creativity
• Connection to AI
steps: Ask child to draw their favorite smart cartoon character.
Talk about what makes it smart.

objective: To identify AI helpers used at home.
explanation:
• AI can be used in vacuums, lights, speakers. 
 • It helps make things easier. 
 • Kids learn how homes can be smart.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Spot the Smart Tool
Materials Needed: Home tour or pictures.
Steps to Follow:
• Walk around and find smart things (e.g. Alexa, robot vacuum).
• Ask what it does.
What Should Be Achieved:
Awareness of AI in home.
What is Gained:
• Real-world connection
• Tech vocabulary
steps: Walk around and find smart things (e.g. Alexa, robot vacuum).

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:

• Ask what each tool does.
What Should Be Achieved:
Imagine AI uses.
What is Gained:

• Understanding convenience

objective: To understand how AI sees pictures and spots things.
explanation:

 • This is used in cameras and apps.

activities.originalText:

Matching visual input with names.

steps: Show pictures and ask child to say what they see.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:

Pretend AI vision.
What is Gained:
• Imagination
• Object recognition

objective: To show how AI makes games smarter and fun.
explanation:
• Many games use AI to challenge or help. 
 • AI can learn how we play. 
 • It makes games more exciting.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Play with a Smart Game
Materials Needed: Simple digital game or toy with AI.
Steps to Follow:
• Play together and see how it responds.
• Ask child what they notice.
What Should Be Achieved:
Interaction with AI-based fun.
What is Gained:
• Attention
• Game strategy
materials: Simple digital game or toy with AI.
steps: Play together and see how it responds.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Make Your Own Game
Materials Needed: Paper, dice, tokens.
Steps to Follow:
• Create a simple pretend AI game.
• Use rules that respond to child’s action.
What Should Be Achieved:
Design thinking.
What is Gained:
• Rule making
• Understanding response systems
steps: Create a simple pretend AI game.
Use rules that respond to child’s action.

originalData.objective: To understand how AI solves puzzles and paths.
originalData.explanation:
• AI finds the best way through a maze. 
• It tries different paths. 
• It remembers what works.
originalData.activity1:
Maze Navigator
Materials Needed: Printed maze sheet, pencil.
Steps to Follow:
• Give a simple maze to the child.
• Let them find the path.
• Discuss how AI tries many paths.
What Should Be Achieved:
Connect AI to solving problems.
What is Gained:
• Problem-solving
• Spatial thinking
originalData.activity2:
Smart Path Game
Materials Needed: Floor tape or chalk, toy.
Steps to Follow:
• Set up a path with dead ends.
• Ask child to guide toy to finish.
• Help with hints like AI.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand AI’s smart decisions.
What is Gained:
• Direction sense
• Logical thinking

objective: To introduce how AI talks and helps people.
explanation:
• AI chatbots answer questions. 
• They use words to understand us. 
• Help in stores and websites.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Chatbot Role Play
Materials Needed: None.
Steps to Follow:
• Pretend to be a chatbot.
• Answer simple questions.
• Use polite words.
What Should Be Achieved:
Experience chatbot talking.
What is Gained:
• Communication
• Imagination

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Ask Me Anything
Materials Needed: List of questions.
Steps to Follow:
• Ask child easy questions.
• Child answers like a chatbot.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice answering clearly.
What is Gained:
• Speaking skills
• Confidence

objective: To explore how AI can create art.
explanation:
• AI makes drawings and music. 
• It learns from patterns. 
• Helps in creative work.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Drawing Robot
Materials Needed: Paper, crayons.
Steps to Follow:
• Draw simple shapes.
• Pretend the robot chooses colors.
What Should Be Achieved:
Link AI to creativity.
What is Gained:
• Creativity
• Color recognition

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Music Maker
Materials Needed: Small instruments or clapping.
Steps to Follow:
• Make beats together.
• Pretend AI mixes sounds.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand AI’s role in music.
What is Gained:
• Rhythm sense
• Teamwork

objective: To learn how AI helps in telling stories.
explanation:
• AI can create stories with ideas. 
• It mixes words and pictures. 
• Helps people write books.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Story Building
Materials Needed: Picture cards.
Steps to Follow:
• Pick cards to make a story.
• Tell story like AI would.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice story creation.
What is Gained:
• Imagination
• Language skills
steps: Pick cards to make a story.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Picture Story
Materials Needed: Drawing paper.
Steps to Follow:
• Draw parts of a story.
• Explain story like AI.
What Should Be Achieved:
Connect visuals to stories.
What is Gained:
• Drawing
• Narrative ability

objective: To show how AI finds clues and solves mysteries.
explanation:
• AI uses clues to find answers. 
• It looks for patterns in data. 
• Helps solve problems.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Clue Hunt
Materials Needed: Objects to hide.
Steps to Follow:
• Hide objects and find clues.
• Pretend to be AI detectives.
What Should Be Achieved:
Learn about clues and patterns.
What is Gained:
• Observation
• Logical thinking

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Pattern Match
Materials Needed: Pattern cards.
Steps to Follow:
• Find matching cards.
• Explain how AI finds matches.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand pattern recognition.
What is Gained:
• Memory
• Analysis skills

objective: To understand how AI predicts weather.
explanation:
• AI watches clouds and wind. 
• It guesses if it will rain or shine. 
• Helps plan days better.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Weather Watch
Materials Needed: Weather chart.
Steps to Follow:
• Observe weather daily.
• Predict tomorrow’s weather.
• Compare with actual.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice prediction.
What is Gained:
• Observation
• Reasoning

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Cloud Detectives
Materials Needed: Photos of clouds.
Steps to Follow:
• Identify cloud types.
• Learn what they mean.
What Should Be Achieved:
Link clouds to weather.
What is Gained:
• Science interest
• Critical thinking

objective: To explore how AI helps animals and nature.
explanation:
• AI tracks animals to keep them safe. 
• It studies how animals live. 
• Helps protect wildlife.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Animal Tracker
Materials Needed: Pictures of animals.
Steps to Follow:
• Identify animals in pictures.
• Talk about AI helping track.
What Should Be Achieved:
Connect AI and animals.
What is Gained:
• Animal knowledge
• Care for nature

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Nature Walk
Materials Needed: Notebook, pencil.
Steps to Follow:
• Walk outside to observe animals.
• Record what is seen.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice observation skills.
What is Gained:
• Patience
• Environmental awareness

objective: To imagine how AI can help learn about the past.
explanation:
• AI studies old pictures and data. 
• It helps understand history. 
• Makes learning fun.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
History Puzzle
Materials Needed: Old photos or drawings.
Steps to Follow:
• Look at old pictures.
• Talk about what they show.
• Pretend AI helps explain.
What Should Be Achieved:
Connect AI to history.
What is Gained:
• Curiosity
• Critical thinking

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Timeline Game
Materials Needed: Cards with events.
Steps to Follow:
• Put events in order.
• Explain with AI’s help.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand sequence of events.
What is Gained:
• Memory
• Logical thinking

objective: To learn how AI helps explore space.
explanation:
• AI controls rovers and satellites. 
• It sends back information. 
• Helps scientists learn more.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Rover Explorer
Materials Needed: Toy rover or box.
Steps to Follow:
• Pretend to explore another planet.
• Avoid obstacles and find samples.
What Should Be Achieved:
Learn about AI in space.
What is Gained:
• Motor skills
• Space knowledge

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
What AI Sees
Materials Needed: Satellite images.
Steps to Follow:
• Look at images and guess what AI sees.
• Talk about Earth shapes.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice observation.
What is Gained:
• Visual thinking
• Space interest
steps: Look at images and guess what AI sees.

objective: To explore how AI solves complex puzzles.
explanation:
• AI tries many moves to solve puzzles. 
• It learns from mistakes. 
• Helps in games and research.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Puzzle Solver
Materials Needed: Simple puzzles or blocks.
Steps to Follow:
• Try to solve puzzles step-by-step.
• Talk about AI trying again if stuck.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand AI learning.
What is Gained:
• Persistence
• Problem-solving
steps: Talk about AI trying again if stuck.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Move It Right
Materials Needed: Board game or cards.
Steps to Follow:
• Play a simple game.
• Think about best moves like AI.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice decision making.
What is Gained:
• Strategy
• Critical thinking
steps: Think about best moves like AI.

objective: To help children see how AI finds patterns in things.
explanation:
• AI looks for patterns in colors, sounds, or actions. 
 • These patterns help it learn and guess what comes next. 
 • It’s like solving puzzles!

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Pattern Detective
Materials Needed: Beads, colored paper.
Steps to Follow:
• Make a color pattern like red-blue-red-blue.
• Ask the child to continue it.
• Try new patterns: size, shape, or number.
What Should Be Achieved:
Spot and follow patterns.
What is Gained:
• Logical thinking
• Visual memory
steps: Make a color pattern like red
Ask the child to continue it.
Try new patterns: size, shape, or number.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
What Comes Next?
Materials Needed: Printed shape sequences.
Steps to Follow:
• Show shape pattern cards.
• Child guesses the next shape.
• Explain how AI guesses using patterns.
What Should Be Achieved:
Predict based on learned rules.
What is Gained:
• Reasoning
• Intro to AI learning
steps: Explain how AI guesses using patterns.

objective: To explore how AI understands sounds and words.
explanation:
• AI listens to voices and sounds. 
 • It turns sound into text or action. 
 • Voice assistants use this skill.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Echo Game
Materials Needed: None.
Steps to Follow:
• Say a sentence clearly.
• Child repeats like an AI.
• Talk about how AI “hears” to repeat.
What Should Be Achieved:
Mimic speech understanding.
What is Gained:
• Sound clarity
• Listening skills
steps: Talk about how AI “hears” to repeat.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Sound Sorter
Materials Needed: Sound clips or mimic voices.
Steps to Follow:
• Play or make animal and object sounds.
• Ask the child to group them.
• Talk about how AI knows differences.
What Should Be Achieved:
Grouping by sound.
What is Gained:
• Categorization
• Auditory awareness
steps: Play or make animal and object sounds.
Ask the child to group them.
Talk about how AI knows differences.

objective: To show how AI creates pictures using ideas.
explanation:
• AI can draw from words or parts of images. 
 • It learns styles and adds details. 
 • It imagines like an artist!

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Style Mix-Up
Materials Needed: Pictures of art styles (cartoon, realistic).
Steps to Follow:
• Show different art styles.
• Ask child to mix them in one drawing.
• Compare how AI blends styles.
What Should Be Achieved:
Create using mixed patterns.
What is Gained:
• Artistic exploration
• Visual learning
steps: Ask child to mix them in one drawing.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Word to Picture
Materials Needed: Words like “robot dog,” “flying tree.”
Steps to Follow:
• Say a funny combo.
• Child draws it.
• Discuss how AI turns words into images.
What Should Be Achieved:
Visualizing from description.
What is Gained:
• Imagination
• Conceptual thinking
steps: Discuss how AI turns words into images.

topic: AI and the Magic of Sorting
objective: To teach how AI groups similar things together.
explanation:
• AI learns by sorting objects by features. 
 • It can group by color, shape, sound, or more. 
 • Helps in organizing big data.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Shape Cluster
Materials Needed: Blocks of different shapes.
Steps to Follow:
• Spread blocks randomly.
• Child sorts into groups.
• Compare to AI sorting data.
What Should Be Achieved:
Sort by logic.
What is Gained:
• Grouping skill
• Understanding classification

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Odd One Out
Materials Needed: Toy sets with one mismatch.
Steps to Follow:
• Show 3 similar, 1 odd item.
• Ask child to spot the odd one.
• Talk about how AI learns this.
What Should Be Achieved:
Spotting anomalies.
What is Gained:
• Attention to detail
• Pattern spotting
steps: Ask child to spot the odd one.
Talk about how AI learns this.

objective: To introduce the idea of how AI stores and recalls data.
explanation:
• AI keeps memories in its system. 
 • It uses past data to make decisions. 
 • This helps it learn over time.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Memory Match
Materials Needed: Memory card game.
Steps to Follow:
• Flip cards and find pairs.
• Relate this to how AI remembers.
• Ask child how remembering helps decisions.
What Should Be Achieved:
Memory as learning.
What is Gained:
• Short-term memory
• AI comparison
steps: Relate this to how AI remembers.
Ask child how remembering helps decisions.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Recall Robot
Materials Needed: Drawn symbols or objects.
Steps to Follow:
• Show 5 items for 10 seconds.
• Hide and ask child to recall.
• Compare with how AI saves info.
What Should Be Achieved:
Retain and recall.
What is Gained:
• Focus
• Retention skills
steps: Hide and ask child to recall.
Compare with how AI saves info.

objective: To explore how chatbots talk with people.
explanation:
• AI can answer questions like a human. 
 • It uses words it learned from reading. 
 • Used in phones and websites.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Build a Bot Chat
Materials Needed: Paper and pencil.
Steps to Follow:
• Child creates a paper chatbot face.
• You ask questions; they reply like a bot.
• Discuss how bots think before replying.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice bot logic.
What is Gained:
• Role-play
• Understanding AI logic
steps: Child creates a paper chatbot face.
You ask questions; they reply like a bot.
Discuss how bots think before replying.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Right Reply
Materials Needed: Question flashcards.
Steps to Follow:
• Show a question.
• Give 3 reply choices.
• Ask child to choose best answer.
What Should Be Achieved:
Choose context replies.
What is Gained:
• Context learning
• Decision-making
steps: Ask child to choose best answer.

objective: To introduce the idea of emotional AI.
explanation:
• Some AIs try to read emotions. 
 • They look at faces, voices, and words. 
 • It helps them act kindly.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Face Feelings
Materials Needed: Emotion flashcards.
Steps to Follow:
• Show happy, sad, angry faces.
• Ask child to guess the feeling.
• Talk about how AI guesses emotions.
What Should Be Achieved:
Recognize feelings.
What is Gained:
• Empathy
• Observation
steps: Ask child to guess the feeling.
Talk about how AI guesses emotions.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Voice Mood
Materials Needed: Say sentences in different tones.
Steps to Follow:
• Say “I’m fine” in happy/sad/angry tone.
• Ask child to guess mood.
• Link to how AI hears feelings.
What Should Be Achieved:
Spot tone changes.
What is Gained:
• Listening skills
• Emotional learning
steps: Link to how AI hears feelings.

objective: To explain how AI makes true/false choices.
explanation:
• AI often answers yes/no or true/false. 
 • It uses logic rules to decide. 
 • Like flipping switches in its brain.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Logic Switch
Materials Needed: Flashcards with questions.
Steps to Follow:
• Ask simple questions: “Is sky blue?”
• Child answers yes or no.
• Explain how AI decides similarly.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand logic checks.
What is Gained:
• Decision logic
• Truth reasoning

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
If-Then Fun
Materials Needed: Paper and pen.
Steps to Follow:
• Write “If I clap, then you jump.”
• Try different if-then combos.
• Explain AI also uses such rules.
What Should Be Achieved:
Action based on logic.
What is Gained:
• Rule-following
• Logical play
steps: Write “If I clap, then you jump.”

objective: To show how AI learns by training.
explanation:
• AI doesn’t know things at first. 
 • We teach it using examples. 
 • The more we teach, the better it gets.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Picture Trainer
Materials Needed: Photos of animals.
Steps to Follow:
• Show 3 cat photos, 3 dogs.
• Ask child to teach AI to tell them apart.
• Use “This is a cat” etc.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand training process.
What is Gained:
• Teaching skill
• Categorization
steps: Ask child to teach AI to tell them apart.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
AI Learns Names
Materials Needed: Family photo cards.
Steps to Follow:
• Say each person’s name with a photo.
• Ask AI (you) to recall.
• Talk about how AI improves.
What Should Be Achieved:
AI memory builds.
What is Gained:
• Memory logic
• Pattern naming
steps: Say each person’s name with a photo.

objective: To understand how AI learns from errors.
explanation:
• AI makes guesses and checks if it’s right. 
 • When wrong, it tries again differently. 
 • This is how it gets smarter.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Learning Loops
Materials Needed: Pencil, paper.
Steps to Follow:
• Write 3 simple math problems.
• Solve once, check, and retry mistakes.
• Talk about how retrying helps.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice learning from errors.
What is Gained:
• Growth mindset
• AI feedback logic
steps: Solve once, check, and retry mistakes.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
AI Retry Race
Materials Needed: Timer, puzzle.
Steps to Follow:
• Try solving puzzle in time.
• If wrong, adjust and retry faster.
What Should Be Achieved:
See how retry improves result.
What is Gained:
• Speed with reflection
• Problem-solving strategy
steps: If wrong, adjust and retry faster.

objective: To introduce how AI detects patterns.
explanation:
• AI looks at data to find regular things. 
 • Patterns help AI predict. 
 • Used in games, weather, and more.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:

Materials Needed: Beads or blocks.
Steps to Follow:
• Create color patterns with beads.
• Ask child to continue or fix broken pattern.
What Should Be Achieved:
Detect and continue patterns.
What is Gained:
• Pattern recognition
• Focused observation
steps: Ask child to continue or fix broken pattern.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Prediction Time
Materials Needed: List of days and temperatures.
Steps to Follow:
• Look at 5 days’ data.
• Ask what tomorrow might be.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice pattern-based thinking.
What is Gained:
• Data reading
• Logical reasoning

objective: To understand step-by-step thinking.
explanation:
• AI follows rules in steps. 
 • Just like giving a robot clear orders. 
 • No guesswork, only logic.

activities.originalText:
Order Me!

Steps to Follow:
• Ask child to guide you to a chair step-by-step.
• Follow exactly.
• Show what happens with wrong steps.
What Should Be Achieved:
Learn how instructions work.
What is Gained:
• Clarity in thought
• Instructional logic

What Should Be Achieved:
Follow commands to complete path.
What is Gained:
• Sequencing
• Spatial awareness

objective: To show how AI mimics behavior.

• Do task once.
• Child pretends to be AI and repeats.

Imitate with accuracy.
What is Gained:
• Action memory
• Step learning

topic: The AI That Learns From You
objective: To understand machine learning through feedback loops.
explanation:
• AI improves when it gets feedback.
• Just like a student, it learns from mistakes.
• You help it get smarter with your input.

activities.originalText:

Steps to Follow:
• Give a task and correct mistakes as they act.
• Repeat until it’s perfect.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand how feedback trains AI.
What is Gained:
• Communication
• Learning reinforcement

• Logical thinking
• Pattern prediction

originalData.activity1:
Memory Sorter

• Show items to “train” memory.

• Sorting skills
• Data association

Data Detective

What is Gained:
• Analytical skills
• Pattern recall

activities.name: Activity 1

• Emotional awareness
• Visual matching
steps: Discuss how AI might guess the emotion.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Voice Mood Test

• Say a sentence in happy/sad/scared tone.
• Guess the emotion each time.
• Discuss how tone affects meaning.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand tone recognition.
What is Gained:
• Listening skill
• AI empathy basics
steps: Say a sentence in happy/sad/scared tone.

• Problem solving

objective: To understand how AI decides between options.

• AI uses rules and data to make choices.

objective: To learn how AI can be fooled with wrong data.
explanation:
• AI trusts its training data too much.
• If tricked, it can make mistakes.
• This is why testing AI is important.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Fool the Robot
Materials Needed: Optical illusions or tricky questions.
Steps to Follow:
• Show examples where AI might fail.
• Ask why it could be confused.
What Should Be Achieved:
See AI’s limits.
What is Gained:
• Curiosity
• Critical questioning
steps: Show examples where AI might fail.
Ask why it could be confused.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Spot the Error
Materials Needed: Pictures with hidden flaws.
Steps to Follow:
• Look for odd or misplaced items.
• Discuss how AI might react.
What Should Be Achieved:
Explore bias and confusion in AI.
What is Gained:
• Observation
• Understanding AI flaws
steps: Look for odd or misplaced items.

objective: To explain how AI uses loops to repeat tasks.
explanation:
• Loops help AI do jobs again and again.
• Saves time and increases speed.
• Used in games, robots, and software.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Loop Dance
Materials Needed: None.
Steps to Follow:
• Create 3 dance steps and repeat 3 times.
• Show how loops save instructions.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand repeat logic.
What is Gained:
• Memory
• Pattern rhythm
steps: Create 3 dance steps and repeat 3 times.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Code the Repeater
Materials Needed: Paper and pen.
Steps to Follow:
• Write a fake AI rule (e.g., jump 2x, turn left).
• Repeat actions using loops.
What Should Be Achieved:
Visualize loop-based behavior.
What is Gained:
• Logic
• Sequencing
steps: Write a fake AI rule (e.g., jump 2x, turn left).

objective: To explore how AI interprets images and shapes.

• Math-art link
• Pixel understanding

objective: To explore how robots use decision trees to choose actions.
explanation:
• Robots use a kind of “if this, then that” logic. 
 • This helps them choose what to do. 
 • It’s called a decision tree.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Decision Tree Drawing
Materials Needed: Paper, pencil.
Steps to Follow:
• Create a simple robot scenario (e.g., cleaning room).
• Draw a tree of choices: If room is dirty → clean.
• Add more “if” paths.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand how robots decide.
What is Gained:
• Logical reasoning
• Visualization
steps: Create a simple robot scenario (e.g., cleaning room).
Draw a tree of choices: If room is dirty → clean.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Choice Machine
Materials Needed: Flashcards with actions.
Steps to Follow:
• Present a situation (e.g., it’s raining).
• Pick correct response card using “if-then” logic.
• Build chains of choices.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice of AI logic.
What is Gained:
• Problem-solving
• AI flow understanding

objective: To understand how AI tries to learn like the human brain.
explanation:
• Neural networks are made of layers that learn patterns. 
 • Each layer passes information to the next. 
 • That’s how AI recognizes things.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
AI Layer Stack
Materials Needed: Paper, colored blocks or cups.
Steps to Follow:
• Stack blocks as input, hidden, output layers.
• Pass a message through each.
• Each layer “transforms” it.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand layers in networks.
What is Gained:
• Layered thinking
• AI model basics
steps: Stack blocks as input, hidden, output layers.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Pattern Teacher
Materials Needed: Pattern cards.
Steps to Follow:
• Show patterns to child.
• Let them “train” a pretend AI to recognize it.
• Add variations over time.
What Should Be Achieved:
Simulation of AI learning.
What is Gained:
• Pattern recognition
• Concept of training data
steps: Let them “train” a pretend AI to recognize it.

objective: To learn how AI remembers important details.
explanation:
• AI has something like memory, called weights. 
 • It helps AI “remember” what is important. 
 • These are adjusted as AI learns.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Memory Match AI-Style
Materials Needed: Picture cards.
Steps to Follow:
• Play memory match, but assign “weights” to each card.
• Try to guess which will be remembered more.
What Should Be Achieved:
Feel how AI gives priority.
What is Gained:
• AI learning logic
• Memory game with a twist
steps: Play memory match, but assign “weights” to each card.
Try to guess which will be remembered more.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Weighted Choices
Materials Needed: Marbles, jars.
Steps to Follow:
• Assign different “importance” to jars.
• Drop marbles based on what’s most important.
• Adjust as you go.
What Should Be Achieved:
See how AI adjusts weights.
What is Gained:
• Concept of importance
• Dynamic thinking
steps: Drop marbles based on what’s most important.

objective: To understand the role of feedback in AI learning.
explanation:
• AI gets better by checking mistakes. 
 • Feedback tells it if it was right or wrong. 
 • This helps AI improve.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Yes-No Trainer
Materials Needed: Question cards.
Steps to Follow:
• Play teacher-student: AI guesses, child gives feedback.
• Use yes/no until AI gets better.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand learning by correction.
What is Gained:
• Iterative learning
• Correction logic
steps: student: AI guesses, child gives feedback.
Use yes/no until AI gets better.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
AI Draws Again
Materials Needed: Paper, crayons.
Steps to Follow:
• AI (you) draws something.
• Child gives clues to improve it.
• Repeat until it’s accurate.
What Should Be Achieved:
Simulate training with feedback.
What is Gained:
• Creative logic
• Process improvement
steps: Child gives clues to improve it.

objective: To learn that AI makes mistakes and how it learns from them.
explanation:
• AI can give wrong answers. 
 • Mistakes help AI improve. 
 • Like humans, it learns over time.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Spot the Error
Materials Needed: Flashcards with right/wrong answers.
Steps to Follow:
• Show cards, ask child to guess which is AI’s wrong answer.

Understand fallibility in AI.

• Error awareness
• Thinking beyond output
steps: Show cards, ask child to guess which is AI’s wrong answer.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Correct the Robot
Materials Needed: Toy robot, command cards.
Steps to Follow:
• Give robot incorrect instructions on purpose.
• Let child fix the steps.
• Repeat with variations.
What Should Be Achieved:
Learn from AI’s trial and error.
What is Gained:
• Debugging thinking
• Problem-solving
steps: Give robot incorrect instructions on purpose.

objective: To learn about how AI follows instructions.

• Cause-effect link

Learn from errors.
What is Gained:
• Problem-solving
• Learning process

Ask child to suggest a fix.

originalData.objective: To understand how AI learns from mistakes.
originalData.explanation:
• AI makes mistakes, then adjusts. 
 • It needs feedback to improve. 
 • This is called training.
originalData.activity1:
Spot the Glitch
Materials Needed: Printed patterns with errors.
Steps to Follow:
• Show AI-designed patterns with a flaw.
• Ask child to find and correct them.
• Discuss how AI is corrected.
What Should Be Achieved:
Spotting AI errors.
What is Gained:
• Attention to detail
• Feedback concepts
originalData.activity2:
Fix the Robot
Materials Needed: Toy robot or pretend setup.
Steps to Follow:
• Make the robot do a wrong action.
• Ask child to suggest a fix.
• Try again.
What Should Be Achieved:
Learn from errors.
What is Gained:
• Problem-solving
• Learning process

objective: To explore how AI reads feelings.
explanation:
• AI uses face, voice, and words to guess emotion. 
 • Not always accurate. 
 • Helps in games and care.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Guess That Mood
Materials Needed: Emotion flashcards.
Steps to Follow:
• Show a card and ask child to mimic it.
• Talk about how AI might read this.
• Discuss challenges.
What Should Be Achieved:
Explore expression recognition.
What is Gained:
• Emotional intelligence
• Empathy
steps: Show a card and ask child to mimic it.
Talk about how AI might read this.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Feeling Sort
Materials Needed: List of emojis or words.
Steps to Follow:
• Group by happy, sad, angry, etc.
• Compare how AI might label them.
• Talk about mistakes AI can make.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understanding AI emotion tags.
What is Gained:
• Vocabulary
• AI limitations

objective: To learn how AI solves puzzles and games.
explanation:
• AI plays games by using rules and patterns. 
 • It keeps trying until it wins. 
 • This is a way of learning.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Bot Puzzle Master
Materials Needed: Puzzle board or Sudoku sheet.
Steps to Follow:
• Start puzzle, give AI-style hints.
• Use if-then steps.
• Discuss how bots do it faster.
What Should Be Achieved:
AI approach to solving.
What is Gained:
• Reasoning
• Step-by-step thinking
steps: Discuss how bots do it faster.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Try-Fail-Win
Materials Needed: Maze or logic puzzle.
Steps to Follow:
• Attempt different paths.
• Mark fails, retry better.
• Note what was learned.
What Should Be Achieved:
Trial-and-error method.
What is Gained:
• Persistence
• AI learning flow

objective: To show how AI makes and learns music.
explanation:
• AI listens and creates music. 
 • It can remix or write new songs. 
 • It learns from many samples.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Rhythm AI
Materials Needed: Drum or tapping surface.
Steps to Follow:
• Tap out a beat.
• Ask child to predict next rhythm.
• Talk about AI pattern learning.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand rhythmic prediction.
What is Gained:
• Listening skill
• Music pattern sense
steps: Ask child to predict next rhythm.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Compose Me!
Materials Needed: Simple music app.
Steps to Follow:
• Let child add sounds and create tune.
• Add “AI suggestions” like faster/slower.
• Compare versions.
What Should Be Achieved:
Music creation experience.
What is Gained:
• Creativity
• Music-AI link
steps: Let child add sounds and create tune.

objective: To explore voice recognition by AI.
explanation:
• AI hears and knows who is speaking. 
 • Each voice has a unique print. 
 • It helps with security and assistants.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Voice Match
Materials Needed: Recordings from family members.
Steps to Follow:
• Play clips and guess the speaker.
• Compare with AI voice tech.
• Discuss voice prints.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand voice identity.
What is Gained:
• Auditory memory
• Tech appreciation
steps: Play clips and guess the speaker.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Say the Secret
Materials Needed: Password phrase.
Steps to Follow:
• Child says phrase in different voices.
• Talk about voice unlocking.
• Try saying it wrong.
What Should Be Achieved:
Voice verification concept.
What is Gained:
• Curiosity
• Cyber awareness
steps: Child says phrase in different voices.

objective: To understand how AI sees and detects.
explanation:
• AI uses cameras to detect faces, shapes, or colors. 
 • It’s used in phones, cars, and more. 
 • Called computer vision.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Object Finder
Materials Needed: Set of mixed items.
Steps to Follow:
• Show picture of item.
• Ask child to find matching object.
• Mimic how AI scans for matches.
What Should Be Achieved:
Visual matching concept.
What is Gained:
• Fast recognition
• Search skills
steps: Ask child to find matching object.
Mimic how AI scans for matches.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Color Coder
Materials Needed: Colored paper or blocks.
Steps to Follow:
• Give sorting challenge by color.
• Add twist like sort only red & green.
• Show how AI filters by input.
What Should Be Achieved:
Color filtering idea.
What is Gained:
• Sorting logic
• Focus skill
steps: Add twist like sort only red & green.
Show how AI filters by input.

objective: To learn how humans train AI.
explanation:
• AI learns from examples we give. 
 • Good data = smart AI. 
 • Bad data = confused AI.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Right or Wrong
Materials Needed: Picture cards (right/wrong).
Steps to Follow:
• Show cat picture and say “cat.”
• Show dog and say “cat” (wrong).
• Ask child what AI would learn.
What Should Be Achieved:
Learn about input accuracy.
What is Gained:
• Cause-effect link
• Teaching mindset
steps: Ask child what AI would learn.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Feed the Bot
Materials Needed: Toy with open mouth or bin.
Steps to Follow:
• Give toy good items (food), then bad (trash).
• Discuss what it should learn.
• Compare results.
What Should Be Achieved:
See impact of data quality.
What is Gained:
• Understanding training
• Quality importance
materials: Toy with open mouth or bin.
steps: Give toy good items (food), then bad (trash).
